OTHER PROGRAMS INCLUDE:THE BLOCK - THE BLOCK IS THE LARGEST ADAPTIVE REUSE PROJECT IN CHATTANOOGA'S HISTORY, TURNING THE OLD BIJOU THEATER INTO A VIBRANT URBAN CENTERPIECE; INCLUDING ROCK/CREEK OUTFITTERS; CHATTZ COFFEE AND HIGH POINT CLIMBING AND FITNESS, A 23,000 SQUARE FOOT STATE OF THE ART CLIMBING AND BOULDERING GYM WITH A 16,500 SQUARE FOOT CLIMBING WALL ON THE BROAD STREET FACE OF THE BUILDING. ITS PRIMARY PURPOSE IS TO BRING MORE VISITORS TO THE RIVERFRONT DISTRICT AND TO FILL IN AN EMPTY SPACE IN THE HEART OF THE DISTRICT, THUS PROMOTING ECONOMIC ACTIVITY AND VIBRANCY THROUGHOUT DOWNTOWN.UNUM DOWNTOWN CAMPUS STUDY: THIS STUDY EVALUATED THE POTENTIAL FOR DEVELOPMENT OF A LARGE PORTION OF LAND CONTROLLED BY UNUM ON THE PERIMETER OF THE CITY CENTER PLANNING AREA. THE RESULTING PLAN CLEARLY REVEALS THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE UNUM PROPERTY TO THE FUTURE GROWTH OF DOWNTOWN CHATTANOOGA. THE PLANS CALL FOR THE CREATION OF AN EXCITING, MIXED-USE, PEDESTRIAN-ORIENTED DOWNTOWN NEIGHBORHOOD. UNUM EXECUTIVES HAVE ACKOWLEDGED THEIR INTEREST IN EXPLORING OPPORTUNITIES FOR DEVELOPMENT AND RECOGNIZE, NOT ONLY THE VALUE OF THE PROPERTY, BUT ITS SIGNIFICANCE TO THE SURROUNDING NEIGHBORHOODS AND TO THE CITY. VINE STREET CORRIDOR STUDY: THIS STUDY LOOKS AT THE CRITICAL LINK BETWEEN VINE STREET AND THE UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE AT CHATTANOOGA (UTC) CAMPUS AND DOWNTOWN. CURRENTLY IT IS COMPRISED OF SURFACE PARKING LOTS AND BUILDINGS IN VARIOUS CONDITIONS RANGING FROM STUDENT HOUSING TO SMALL RETAIL ESTABLISHMENTS. THE STRATEGY FOR UNUM'S VINE STREET PROPERTIES CALLS FOR INCREMENTALLY REDEVELOPING THE SURFACE PARKING LOTS INTO STREET-FRONTING BUILDINGS WITH PARKING EITHER SURFACE OR STRUCTURED LOCATED BEHIND. MARKET-RATE RESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS WITH STOREFRONTS ON THE GROUND FLOOR WOULD CREATE A SAFE AND PLEASANT ENVIRONMENT. BOTH THE UNIVERSITY AND UNUM'S DEVELOPER WILL WIDEN THE EXISTING SIDEWALK INTO A BEAUTIFUL PROMENADE WITH PLANTING AREAS, SIDEWALK ZONES FOR PEDESTRIAN MOVEMENT, AND TERRACE AREAS IN FRONT OF COMMERCIAL STOREFRONTS FOR OUTSIDE CAFES, RETAILING, AND ADDITIONAL LANDSCAPING. UTC AND UNUM SHARE THE BELIEF THAT THIS GENEROUS PROMENADE IS AN EXTRAORDINARY OPPORTUNITY TO BETTER CONNECT THE UTC CAMPUS TO DOWNTOWN CHATTANOOGA. RETAIL RECRUITMENT FOR DOWNTOWN: THIS INITIATIVE IS INTENDED TO RECRUIT NEW COMMERCIAL RETAILERS TO LOCATE DOWNTOWN, SINCE ECONOMIC VIABILITY IS VIEWED AS CRUCIAL TO THE SUSTAINABILITY OF THE ENTIRE DOWNTOWN REVITALIZATION EFFORT. OVER THE PAST YEAR, 38 NEW RESTAURANTS AND RETAILERS HAVE OPENED DOWNTOWN. MILLER PLAZA: MILLER PLAZA IS AN URBAN PUBLIC PARK CONSTRUCTED ALMOST THREE DECADES AGO IN THE HEART OF DOWNTOWN CHATTANOOGA; IT WAS BUILT BOTH TO PROVIDE A MODEL OF GOOD URBAN DESIGN FOR "ACTIVE PARK USE," AND TO PROVIDE A VENUE FOR AN ENORMOUS VARIETY OF ANIMATING ACTIVITIES FOR DOWNTOWN. WHEN IT WAS CONSTRUCTED, DOWNTOWN CHATTANOOGA WAS SLIDING DOWNHILL WITH ABANDONED RETAIL STORES, CLOSED MOVIE THEATERS, OFFICES AND RESIDENCES RELOCATING TO OUTLYING SURBURBAN AREAS, AND A VACUUM OF ATTRACTIVE ACTIVITY AND ANIMATION, EXPECIALLY AFTER WORK HOURS ENDED. MILLER PLAZA WAS THE FIRST BEACON FOR THE REVIVAL OF DOWNTOWN CHATTANOOGA, AND MILLER PLAZA NOW SERVES AS THE HOME FOR FOUR RESTAURANTS/SANDWICH SHOPS; SEASONAL FRIDAY NIGHT CONCERT SERIES FROM MEMORIAL DAY TO SEPTEMBER; AND A VENUE FOR MANY DOZENS OF CIVIC GATHERINGS AND ACTIVITIES. MILLER PLAZA IS OWNED BY THE RIVERCITY COMPANY AND IT CONTINUES TO PROVIDE THE SOCIAL ANCHOR FOR EVENTS AND ANIMATION WITHIN THE CITY CENTER DISTRICT OF DOWNTOWN CHATTANOOGA. RETURN TO THE RIVER INITIATIVES: THIS PROGRAM'S PURPOSE IS TO ATTRACT PEOPLE TO LIVE, WORK, AND PLAY IN THE RIVERFRONT DISTRICT. EXPENDITURES RELATE TO PLANNING FOR FUTURE DEVELOPMENT, ANIMATION OF EXISTING PUBLIC SPACES.

Lead to Serve trained several thousand men in 2014 in approximately 25 different countries.

column6: Smart Start Healthy Family Services: This program works to strengthen families' support systems and raise awareness of service providers, decision-makers and the public about the early childhood system that supports the healthy development of children. Triple P(C) (Positive Parenting Program) Level 4 and Motheread, Inc. programs were offered to high-risk populations with one or more risk factors of child maltreatment. Touchpoints training and reflective practices were provided to caregivers working with young children and their families. SSFHS oversaw community outreach and education events, often in collaboration with the PUZZLES program, acted as liaisons to community task forces and committees such as the Obesity Prevention Coalition and the Rethink Your Drink Campaign, oversaw the Children' Champion awards and supports the First 2000 Days Summit.

Smart Start Intervention/Inclusion Services: The goal of this activity is to support the full inclusion of young children in child care who have or are at risk for special developmental or behavioral needs. Specialists provide consultation and technical assistance to classroom professionals and demonstrate developmental therapies for children as well as training and information for parents.

Smart Start Programming & Evaluation: This program oversees and supports delivery of all funded services by overseeing, monitoring, and maintaining contracting & contract fulfilment, program evaluation and outcomes tracking, and overall project compliance and effectiveness. Reports to Board of Directors on progress towards long- and short-term goals for agency and programs.

Smart Start Triple P :Triple P offers evidence-based principles and advice providing tools that parents need to raise confident, healthy children, and to build stronger family relationships. Parents must be referred from NHC Department of Social Services.

Smart Start Raising A Reader: Literacy consultants trained in this evidence-based program provide early childhood professionals with materials and strategies for engaging families in reading activities. Families are given tools to develop book sharing routines with their child - a practice that is shown to build pre-literacy skills in and advance early literacy for children birth to age five.

Smart Start Baby FAST: This research-based program nurtures young parents through mentoring and education to strengthen family and social relationships and access community support services while setting and reaching educational goals.

Smart Start ABCD (Assuring Better Health and Child Development): In collaboration with Community Care of the Lower Cape Fear, SSNHC serves as a regional hub for six counties in southeastern NC. Funded by Race to the Top Funds, this project works directly with medical practices serving young children to assure regular check-ups and developmental screenings, and supports best practices for providing appropriate early interventions.

CF United Way Motheread B.A.B.Y.: Motheread B.A.B.Y (Birth & Beginning Years) is a 10-week long session of highly effective, group counseling programming designed to build nurturing and other skills for high-risk groups of mothers of young children. The program uses quality children's literature to support better understanding of child development and other relevant topics, provide literacy engagement, foster bonding between the mother and baby, empower at-risk mothers, and promote use of support systems.

Smart Start Reach Out and Read: This nationally recognized, evidence-based program encourages school success by partnering with medical providers to "prescribe" books and shared reading activities for families. At well check-up visit, children ages 6 months to 6 years receive a new, high quality age-appropriate, book. Primary care providers coach parents in developmentally appropriate reading activities to use at home.
Shape NC: Grant to Childcare facility to support the creation of model outdoor sites and to incorporate regular activities to reduce obesity in children ages birth to five.
Scholarships for Child Care: Scholarships for registration fees for parents who received Child Care Subsidy for at least one child age birth to 5.

First 2000 Days Summit: Funding from both NC Early Childhood Foundation & Cape Fear Memorial Foundations. This program provides follow-up support for a faith- based Summit that is held yearly to engage the community in better understanding the critical importance of the first 2000 days of life preceding children's enrollment into kindergarten.

Corning Foundation "Building Bridges" Kindergarten Readiness: A activity for supporting children's transition from child care, Head Start, and NCPreK programs to public school system kindergarten classrooms by assisting early care teachers with preparation strategies, providing parents with enrollment and school requirement information, and delivering additional, transitional supports to 2 local elementary schools.

Dsc: HAYWARD CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTER - PROVIDES THERAPEUTIC PRESCHOOL AND CHILDCARE AS WELL AS PARENT EDUCTION. IN FISCAL YEAR 2014-2015, 6,541 DAYS OF THERAPEUTIC CHILDCARE/PRESCHOOL WERE PROVIDED FOR 57 CHILDREN, AGE EIGHTEEN MONTHS TO FIVE YEARS, IDENTIFIED AS BEING AT RISK OF ABUSE OR NEGLECT AND APPROXIMATELY 55 PARENTS AND FAMILY MEMBERS.THE PROGRAM PROVIDES INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY COUNSELING, PLAY THERAPY, PARENT ENRICHMENT EDUCATION, REFERRALS TO OUTSIDE RESOURCES AND SPECIALIZED ADVOCACY AND COUNSELING TO MILITARY FAMILIES SUFFERING THE IMPACTS OF POST TRAUMATIC STRESS DISORDER, INJURY AND OTHER RESULTS OF WAR EXPOSURE. A GOAL OF THE PROGRAM IS TO HELP FAMILIES DEVELOP A SAFETY NET OF CONNECTIONS TO THEIR COMMUNITY (FRIENDS, CHURCH, CLUBS, ETC.) AND TO DEVELOP THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO NAVIGAGE PUBLIC/PRIVATE SOCIAL SERVICE SYSTEMS TO ACCESS SUPPORTS THAT ENSURE A HEALTHY FAMILY ENVIRONMENT AND THAT PREVENT FUTURE ABUSE OR NEGLECT.

FAMILY VISITATION SERVICES - PROVIDES SUPERVISED VISITS AND PROMOTES HEALTHY FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS. IN FISCAL YEAR 2014-2015 1,874 SUPERVISED VISITS IN A SAFE AND NEUTRAL ENVIRONMENT FOR 469 CHILDREN AND 277 PARENTS/CAREGIVERS WORKING TOWARDS FAMILY REUNIFICATION WERE PROVIDED. SERVICES INCLUDE CHILD DEVELOPMENT EDUCATION AND COACHING FOR PARENTS, AND INPUT TO SAN DIEGO COUNTY CHILD WELFARE SERVICES REGARDING FAMILY READINESS FOR REUNIFICATION. TRANSPORTATION IS PROVIDED, AS NEEDED, TO FACILITATE VISITATION. PRE/POST CONSULTATION IS PROVIDED TO PARENTS TO DELIVER COACHING AND TO TEACH THE DEVELOPMENTAL CAPABILITIES OF THEIR CHILDREN, INCLUDING AGE-APPROPRIATE PLAY, DISCIPLINE, AND SKILL DEVELOPMENT. SUPERVISED VISITATION IS ALSO PROVIDED TO FAMILIES INVOLVED IN DIVORCE OR CUSTODY NEGOTIATION VIA THE FAMILY COURT.

YOUNG PARENT NETWORK - THE YOUNG PARENT NETWORK (YPN) IS AN EVIDENCE BASED TREATMENT PROGRAM DESIGNED TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF PREGNANT AND PARENTING TEENS AND YOUNG ADULTS AGES 24 AND YOUNGER WHO ARE STRUGGLING WITH ISSUES RELATED TO SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND THE EMOTIONAL, FINANCIAL AND PERSONAL DEMANDS OF BEING A PARENT. IN FISCAL YEAR 2014-2015, YPN PROVIDED SERVICES FOR 67 CHILDREN, INCLUDING MINOR TEENS WHO ARE PARENTS, 50 ADULTS AND 54 FAMILIES. SERVICES INCLUDE ASSESSMENT, IN-HOME CASE MANAGEMENT, INDIVIDUAL AND GROUP THERAPY, PEER SUPPORT, PARENTING EDUCATION, AND HEALTHY WAYS OF MANAGING STRESS, AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE INTERVENTION, TREATMENT AND PREVENTION.

column6: Providence High School for children of the Northern San Fernando Valley and surrounding area. School Days - 178 Students - 415.Providence High School is a Catholic, accredited, college-preparatory school for young men and women. The School is located in the San Fernando Valley and serves the Greater Los Angeles area. The School offers a challenging college-preparatory academic program, carefully designed to give students opportunities for growth and experience in preparation for university course work. The School has received full accreditation from the Western Association of Schools and Colleges, and the Western Catholic Educational Association.

RvnAmt: ABCD:THE ASSET-BASED COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT INSTITUTE (ABCD) IS AT THE CENTER OF A LARGE AND GROWING MOVEMENT THAT CONSIDERS LOCAL ASSETS AS THE PRIMARY BUILDING BLOCKS OF SUSTAINABLE COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT. BUILDING ON THE SKILLS OF LOCAL RESIDENTS, THE POWER OF LOCAL ASSOCIATIONS AND THE SUPPORTIVE FUNCTIONS OF LOCAL INSTITUTIONS, ASSET-BASED COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DRAWS UPON EXISTING COMMUNITY STRENGTHS TO BUILD STRONGER, MORE SUSTAINABLE COMMUNITIES FOR THE FUTURE.

ALZHEIMER PROJECT:THE ALZHEIMER'S POETRY PROJECT PERFORMS AND CREATES POETRY WITH PEOPLE LIVING WITH MEMORY LOSS. IN 2014, A TOTAL OF 72 POETRY SESSIONS TOOK PLACE THROUGHOUT WISCONSIN SERVING 970 PEOPLE. HIGHLIGHTS INCLUDED: AN INTERGENERATIONAL WORKSHOP WITH 5TH GRADERS AT ST. JOHN THE BAPTIST SCHOOL AND HOMESTEAD LIVING IN WAUNAKEE; CREATING AND PERFORMING POEMS WITH MADISON CHILDREN'S MUSEUM'S SPARK! GROUP AN EARLY STAGE DEMENTIA GROUP.

CONTRAIL NETWORK:THE CONTRAIL NETWORK IS AN ORGANIZATION THAT COLLECTS AND AGGREGATES FINANCIAL DONATIONS FROM INDIVIDUALS AND INSTITUTIONS TO SUPPORT AND PROMOTE EDUCATION, ENTREPRENEURSHIP AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT STRATEGIES THAT BENEFIT LOW-WEALTH INDIVIDUALS (YOUTH AND ADULTS) AND ECONOMICALLY DISTRESSED COMMUNITIES.

DANE 101:DANE101 IS A LOCALLY (MADISON, WISCONSIN) FOCUSED ONLINE MEDIA SOURCE THAT STRIVES TO PROVIDE INDEPENDENT COVERAGE OF THE NEWS, POLITICS, ARTS AND CULTURE THAT SHAPE OUR AREA AND OUR STATE. DANE101 ALSO REGULARLY ORGANIZES COMMUNITY EVENTS - EVERYTHING FROM CONCERTS AND OPEN MICS, TO VARIETY SHOWS AND BURLESQUE CABARETS. DANE101 CLOSED ITS DOORS IN 2014

DRUM POWER:DRUM POWER IS A YOUTH LEADERSHIP PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES YOUNG PEOPLE WITH AN OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN WEST AFRICAN TRADITIONAL, AFRO-CUBAN AND AFRO BRAZILIAN DRUMMING AND THEIR CULTURAL/HISTORICAL SIGNIFICANCE TO BUILD SELF ESTEEM AND SELF-CONFIDENCE THROUGH DISCOVERING THE REWARDS OF DISCIPLINE, TEAMWORK, CREATIVITY, RESPONSIBILITY AND SELF-RESPECT. THESE ELEMENTS ARE THE FOUNDATIONS OUT OF WHICH COME RESPECT FOR OTHERS, LEADERSHIP AND ULTIMATELY, POSITIVE CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE WORLD.

MINDFULNESS FOR SOCIAL CHANGE:MINDFULNESS FOR SOCIAL CHANGE BRINGS THE BENEFITS OF MINDFULNESS TO SOCIAL CHANGE ORGANIZATIONS. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED FOR STAFF OF SOCIAL CHANGE ORGANIZATIONS, GIVING THEM ADDITIONAL TOOLS TO FOCUS; SELF REGULATE; BETTER DEAL WITH CHAOS, STRESS AND CHANGE; AND BE MORE EFFECTIVE IN MOTIVATING OTHERS TO ACTION. THIS PROJECT DEVELOPS EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND FEATURES A CORE COURSE TAUGHT BY FACULTY WITH EXTENSIVE EXPERIENCE AS MEDITATION AND YOGA TEACHERS AND BY LIFETIME SOCIAL CHANGE ACTIVISTS STEEPED IN THE DAY-TO-DAY CHALLENGES OF BUILDING EFFECTIVE CHANGE ORGANIZATIONS.

POSITIVE WOMEN FOR CHANGE:POSITIVE WOMEN FOR CHANGE (PW4C) RESPONDS TO THE NEEDS OF INDIVIDUALS WHO HAVE SUFFERED TRAUMATIC CIRCUMSTANCES RESULTING IN THE DISARRAY OF PERSONAL AND HOUSEHOLD FINANCES. ESPECIALLY FOCUSING ON OUTREACH TO UNDERSERVED WOMEN, THE PROJECT FOUNDER, KIA STEARN, HAS DESIGNED A PEER COACHING CURRICULUM THAT FOSTERS POSITIVE BEHAVIOR CHANGE, HELPING HER CLIENTS SUCCESSFULLY BUDGET AND MANAGE CASH FLOW ON A LIMITED INCOME AND TO ENGAGE MORE FULLY WITH THEIR COMMUNITY. THE HANDS-ON PROGRAM TEACHES PARTICIPANTS HOW TO IDENTIFY, BUILD AND MAINTAIN HEALTHY RELATIONSHIPS WITH COMMUNITY RESOURCES SPECIFIC TO THEIR NEEDS. PARTICIPANTS LEARN HOW TO MAKE GOOD USE OF SUPPORT SYSTEMS LIKE TRANSPORTATION, FOOD, HOUSING AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AS PART OF THEIR BUDGET AND FINANCIAL PLAN. AT THE SAME TIME, POSITIVE WOMEN FOR CHANGE PROVIDES PARTICIPANTS WITH COMMUNICATION TOOLS LIKE SCRIPTS THAT HELP THEM NEGOTIATE SOLUTIONS AND POSITIVE OUTCOMES WITH BUSINESSES LIKE BANKS AND CREDIT UNIONS, LANDLORDS AND CREDITORS.

SAGA:SAGA WORKS TO:-ASSESS CURRENT GANG ACTIVITY IN THE COMMUNITY AND ANTI-GANG EFFORTS BEING DEPLOYED BY THE SUN PRAIRIE POLICE DEPARTMENT, SUN PRAIRIE SCHOOL DISTRICT, DANE COUNTY, YMCA, STATE LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES, FAITH-BASED AND NON PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, AND APPROPRIATE OTHERS;-IDENTIFY GAPS IN ANTI-GANG STRATEGIES AND POTENTIAL SOLUTIONS TO FILL THOSE GAPS; AND -OUTLINE HOW THE COMMUNITY SCHOOLS INITIATIVE FITS INTO THE ANTI-GANG STRATEGY. USING THE FEDERAL OFFICE OF JUVENILE JUSTICE AND DELINQUENCY PREVENTION ASSESSMENT MANUAL, APPROXIMATELY 92 VOLUNTEERS GATHERED DATA - DEMOGRAPHIC, POLICE AND SCHOOL DATA, CONDUCTED COMMUNITY CONVERSATIONS AND IDENTIFIED AVAILABLE SERVICES TO YOUTH IN OUR COMMUNITY. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE GATHERED INTO A REPORT FOR THE COMMUNITY TO BE COMPLETED IN EARLY 2015.

STATE STREET FAMILY:THE FRIENDS OF THE STATE STREET FAMILY ("FSSF") PROVIDED 7,800 INDIVIDUAL MEALS OVER THE COURSE OF 2014 TO HOMELESS PEOPLE LIVING OUTSIDE. WE ALSO HAD OVER 1,040 VOLUNTEER HOURS SPREAD OVER 120 VOLUNTEERS TO FEED THOSE INDIVIDUALS. WE ALSO PROVIDED STREET OUTREACH AND ASSISTED SEVERAL HOMELESS SERVICE AGENCIES CONNECT WITH INDIVIDUALS IN THEIR SERVICE MODELS, TOOK PHYSICIANS, NURSES, COUNSELORS AND CASE MANAGERS OUT WITH US TO DO OUTREACH AND SERVED AS A RESOURCE FOR INDIVIDUALS IN NEED OF SERVICES THAT WERE HOMELESS. APPROXIMATELY 19 INDIVIDUAL VOLUNTEERS COMPLETED 1664 HOURS OF VOLUNTEER OUTREACH IN 2014. OTHER VOLUNTEERS ALSO DID MIDNIGHT RUN, WINTER BOOT, BABY ITEMS AND SURVIVAL GEAR DRIVES AND DONATED, TRANSPORTED AND DISTRIBUTED APPROXIMATELY $26,000 WORTH OF GOODS TO HOMELESS INDIVIDUALS AND THEIR SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS FOR BEST DISTRIBUTION (BETHEL HOMELESS SERVICES, THE TRANSITION EDUCATION PROGRAM AND PORCHLIGHT, AS WELL AS PROJECT BABIES AND BRIARPATCH TO NAME THE MAIN ORGS) THE SURVIVAL GEAR DRIVE VOLUNTEERS ENCOMPASSED APPROXIMATELY 86 INDIVIDUALS DOING APPROXIMATELY 745 HOURS OF VOLUNTEER WORK. OVER THE COURSE OF 2014, FSSF WAS DIRECTLY INVOLVED IN HELPING 23 CHRONICALLY HOMELESS INDIVIDUALS GET OFF OF THE STREET AND INTO HOUSING OR TREATMENT PROGRAMS. FSSF WAS ALSO ASKED TO PARTICIPATE IN AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE WITH THE MAYOR'S OFFICE, AND THE HOMELESS SERVICES CONSORTIUM, AND DID SO AS ABLE. WE CONTINUE TO OPERATE AS AN ALL VOLUNTEER ORGANIZATION, THAT IS PRIVATELY FUNDED

WAGON DRIVE:IN AUGUST 2014, THE WAGON DRIVE HELD ITS 7TH SCHOOL AND FOOD SUPPLY DRIVE. KIDS HAVE GATHERED EVERY SUMMER SINCE 2009 (TWO HELD IN 2009) TO COLLECT SCHOOL SUPPLIES, NON-PERISHABLE FOOD, CLEANING SUPPLIES, AND TOILETRY ITEMS. THE WAGON DRIVE JOINED C4CS IN 2014. AT THE AUGUST 2014 DRIVE, KIDS, IN ADDITION TO COLLECTING ITEMS, RAISED $569.93 BY OFFERING A DONATION BASED LEMONADE AND BAKE GOODIE TABLE. BY THE START OF THE SCHOOL YEAR, $1,454.93 TOTAL WAS RAISED. ALL ITEMS COLLECTED AND PURCHASED (THROUGH FUNDS RAISED) WERE PROVIDED TO KNOWN UNNAMED KIDS IN NEED AT FRANKLIN AND RANDALL ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS, MADISON'S TRANSITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (TEP), THE ROAD HOME, ST. MARK'S LUTHERAN CHURCH FOOD PANTRY, AND KIDS LIVING IN THE BAYVIEW NEIGHBORHOOD. 18 KIDS AND 20 ADULTS (NOT ALL PARENTS)VOLUNTEERED TO HAND OUT 1000 FLYERS, AND DURING THE EVENT. WE SERVED 18 FRANKLIN AND RANDALL KINDERGARTENERS, 1ST, 2ND, 3RD, 4TH, AND 5TH GRADERS, AND ROUGHLY 50 MORE KIDS FROM THE BAYVIEW NEIGHBORHOOD RANGING FROM 4K THROUGH 12TH GRADE. MANY MORE KIDS WERE HELPED INDIRECTLY BY US WITH THE OTHER SUPPLIES AND ITEMS DONATED TO TEP, THE ROAD HOME, AND THE FOOD PANTRY. THE NUMBERS WE HELP IS BASED ON THE AMOUNT OF DONATIONS WE BRING IN.

WI EMPATHY GUILD:OFFERED A 7 DAY FAMILY HEART CAMP (FHC) IMMERSION IN COMPASSIONATE COMMUNITY, FOR 97 PEOPLE AGES 1 -62. GROUNDED IN THE PRINCIPLES OF NONVIOLENT COMMUNICATION (NVC). THIS COMMUNITY WAS SERVED BY 18 VOLUNTEERS AND THREE TRAINERS, TWO OF THEM CERTIFIED WITH THE INTERNATIONAL CENTER FOR NONVIOLENT COMMUNICATION (CNVC). ONE BIG CIRCLE (OBC) WEEKEND CAMP FOR 61 PARTICIPANTS, 12 VOLUNTEERS, AND 2 TRAINERS. WE ALSO PROVIDED INFORMATION ON AREA TRAININGS AND PRACTICE GROUPS IN NONVIOLENT COMMUNICATION THROUGH OUR WEBSITE AND NEWSLETTER SENT TO 508 SUBSCRIBERS.

RvnAmt: COMMUNITY INFORMATION AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT: THE SUSTAINABLE JERSEY COMMUNITY INFORMATION & CIVIC ENGAGEMENT TASKFORCE PROGRAM FOCUSES ON PROVIDING NEW JERSEY LOCAL GOVERNMENTS WITH A NEW TOOLBOX TO ENHANCE AND SUPPORT CIVIC ENGAGEMENT. TO ACCOMPLISH THE WORK THE TASKFORCE HAS BROUGHT TOGETHER EXPERTS AND PRACTITIONERS FROM FEDERAL, STATE AND MUNICIPAL GOVERNMENTS TO IDENTIFY NEEDS, DEVELOP BEST PRACTICE STANDARDS AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL HIGH IMPACT PILOT PROJECTS THAT WILL ADVANCE CIVIC ENGAGEMENT. WORK WILL ALSO INCLUDE HOSTING A NJ GOV 2.0 CONFERENCE AND LEARNING EXPO WITH NATIONAL EXPERTS THAT WILL BRING NEW IDEAS AND SHARE THE SUCCESS STORIES OF INNOVATIVE NEXT GENERATION CITIZEN PARTICIPATION MODELS, GOV 2.0, AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT INITIATIVES/PLATFORMS, AND LAUNCHING AN EDUCATION AND TRAINING PROGRAM TARGETING THE FIRST GENERATION OF MUNICIPALITIES. SUSTAINABLE JERSEY ENTERED INTO A MASTER SERVICES AGREEMENT WITH THE COLLEGE OF NEW JERSEY TO RECEIVE ONGOING SERVICES AND FACILITATE CERTAIN SUSTAINABLE JERSEY GRANTS. AS PART OF THE ONGOING SERVICES RECEIVED, IT IS ESTIMATED THAT THE COLLEGE OF NEW JERSEY DONATED $16,209 IN CONTRIBUTIONS AND EXPENSES RELATED TO THE COMMUNITY INFORMATION AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT PROGRAM.

Del Camino Connection was contracted by Tear Fund UK's Inspired Individuals program in 2014 to serve as the connecting, coaching and consulting entity for the Latin American and Caribbean regions. DCC helped review and select 20 men and women from the region, orient them to the program, and provide them with ongoing support and encouragement in order to equip them for their diverse outreach ministries serving the marginalized and suffering. Those participating in the Inspired Individuals program reach out to youth at risk, vulnerable children, women who suffer domestic abuse and violence, activists who seek care of the creation, and other heroic servant leaders. DCC has the privilege of investing in these innovative and passionate leaders as they strive to make a difference through their ministry.

column6: Quality Enhancements/Environmental Ratings: Our Partnership would like to provide high standards for our children. In order to assist facilities in improving their overall quality, a technical assistance activity will be implemented. This activity will utilize a comprehensive approach to technical assistance that includes: customized quality improvement plans consisting of program development, staff professional development and the two component license. The Early Education Specialist (EES) will be available to Jones County facilities interested in improving the quality of care they offer. Plans will be based on the Environmental Rating Scales. Eligible facilities can receive grants of up to $5000.00 for centers and $3000.00 for homes. One to three star facilities may apply based on their improvement plan and willingness to accept subsidized children. Four and five star facilities may apply to improve/increase capacity and their willingness to accept subsidized children. Unregulated facilities are not eligible to participate except under special circumstances approved by NCPC.

Family Support: This activity will provide workshops for parents or caretakers of children birth to five, lending library materials geared towards families, and referrals for parents to other agencies as appropriate. The Family Support Coordinator, Early Education Specialist, Child Care Nurse Consultant, Health Check Coordinators and Program Coordinator will collaborate together to offer free workshops that will address four major topics that will increase parenting skills as it relates to becoming more involved with their child learning, making their home safe, understanding the importance of having regular check-up and managing their child's behavior, Parents will be required to complete four (4) workshops and complete the Parent Survey. The staff listed above and other qualified presenters will provide the training. The Family Support Coordinator will work with local agencies, churches, and Toys for Tots to provide support to parents and their families. This activity will provide educational child care and refreshments for parents and children.

Education Incentive Awards - The Education Incentive activity is designed to pay a stipend to child care providers, teacher assistance in the pre-k program, and child care directors based on the level of education that the teacher has either obtained or is persuing. The stipend increases as the level of education obtained or persued increases. The stipend ranges from $250.00 for the NC Credential to $1000 for the BA/BS degree in ECE or related field. Education Incentive Awards will be paid on a semi-annual basis and are contingent upon the six month contract period. The Early Childhood Specialist will be available to early childhood teachers both in the field and at the Jones County Partnership for Children Office to assist applicants in completing this process. This process will contribute to high quality early childhood programs by reinforcing the need for formal education.

Quality Incentives (formerly Quality Bonus): The Quality Incentive Activity will pay a monthly, per child 0-5, incentive to child care facilities with 3 star or higher rating. Centers and homes participating in the program will document that they accept or are willing to accept children who receive child care subsidies. Three star facilities will be eligible for two years, after which they will have to have increased their star status in order to maintain eligibility. The Early Education Specialist (EES) will be available t Jones County regulated facilities interested in maintaining their higher star status. The EES will assist childcare directors in completing the application process. The incentive payment will help to offset the higher cost of maintaining the star level for the licensed star rated homes and centers that participate.

Dual Subsidy TANF/CCDF: Dual Subsidy Administration will provide administration for child care subsidy including program administration; family outreach and application; eligibility determination; payment processing; annual recertification; and reporting, etc. Dual Subsidy financial assistance will be paid on a direct per child basis for the purchase of care and enhancements for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) eligible or Child Care Development Fund (CCDF) eligible families. This activity will be implemented by the contractor who will report data into the state-level Smart Start Reporting System on a monthly basis. Includes wrap-around care.

Dsc: COASTAL TEAM CHALLENGE: WORLD T.E.A.M. SPORT'S COASTAL TEAM CHALLENGE BRINGS TOGETHER DISABLED AND ABLE-BODIED ATHLETES FOR TWO DAYS OF KAYAKING AND CAMPING IN THE WATERS OFF OF LONG ISLAND. DEBUTING IN 2009 IN THE WATERS OFF OF WASHINGTON STATE, THE CTC INSPIRES AND CHALLENGES ATHLETES OF ALL ABILITIES. EACH TEAM IN THE CHALLENGE CONSISTS OF TWO MEMBERS, ONE WITH A DISABILITY AND ONE WITHOUT. FOR THIS EVENT WORLD TEAM SPORTS PARTNERS WITH INDEPENDENT GROUP HOME LIVING (IGHL), TIME CAPITAL AND AMERICAN PORTFOLIOS TO ALLOW THIS GROUP OF DEVELOPMENTALLY DISABLED ADULTS TO PARTICIPATE IN THIS EVENT. THIS YEAR'S EVENT COVERED OVER 20 MILES OF THE GREAT SOUTH BAY.

RvnAmt: ALL OTHER EVENTS: CELTICS HALF TIME CHALLENGE: THIS WORLD TEAM SPORTS AFFILIATE EVENT ALLOWS YOUNG ATHLETES WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES PROVIDED SPIRITED HALFTIME COMPETITION FOR FANS OF THE NATIONAL BASKETBALL ASSOCIATION'S BOSTON CELTICS. AT SPECIAL BASKETBALL GAMES SPONSORED BY WORLD T.E.A.M. SPORTS AND DIRECTED BY MASSACHUSETTS' ULTIMATE SPORTS PROGRAM, THE COMPETITIONS PROVIDED A THRILLING EXPERIENCE FOR THE YOUNG PARTICIPANTS ON THE FABLED PARQUET COURT OF THE GARDEN. - BRUINS SLED HOCKEY: THIS WORLD TEAM SPORTS AFFILIATE EVENT ALLOWS YOUNG ATHLETES WITH DISABILITIES TO PARTAKE IN THE EXCITING SPORT OF SLED HOCKEY. ATHLETES PARTAKE IN A FULL DAY OF INSTRUCTION AND THEN PLAY A SCRIMMAGE GAME AGAINST EACH OTHER. DURING THE DAY THE ATHLETES MEET MEMBERS OF THE BOSTON BRUINS PROFESSIONAL HOCKEY TEAM. THIS EVENT IS SPONSORED BY WORLD T.E.A.M. SPORTS AND DIRECTED BY MASSACHUSETTS' ULTIMATE SPORTS PROGRAM.

Dsc: In response to the Tropical Cyclone Ian, which struck Tonga in January 2014, we sent a volunteer to give aid to the children and families on that island nation. Those funds were used to purchase the volunteer's airfare, as well as a water pump, medicine, and other supplies for the children.

OPPORTUNITY TEXAS/ RAISE TEXAS: WITH FUNDING AND PARTNERSHIP FROM OPPORTUNITY TEXAS, UWT WORKED WITH EIGHT LOCAL UNITED WAYS IN 2014 TO INCREASE TAX-TIME SAVINGS TO LOW-TO-MODERATE INCOME INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES ACROSS TEXAS. THE PROGRAM PROVIDES $25 INCENTIVES FOR VOLUNTEER INCOME TAX ASSISTANCE (VITA) SITE CLIENTS TO PURCHASE U.S. SERIES I SAVINGS BONDS. IN 2014, 360 TAX FILERS PURCHASED 436 SAVINGS VEHICLES THROUGH THE PROGRAM, THE MAJORITY OF THESE WERE INCREASING THEIR FINANCIAL STABILITY BY SAVING FOR THE FIRST TIME.

column6: EARNED INCOME TAX CREDIT (EITC): THROUGH A FUNDING PARTNERSHIP WITH UNITED WAY WORLDWIDE AND BANK OF AMERICA, UNITED WAYS OF TEXAS WORKED WITH NINE UNITED WAYS AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS STATEWIDE IN 2014 TO CONDUCT OUTREACH AND PROMOTION FOR THE EARNED INCOME TAX CREDIT (EITC) IN CONJUNCTION WITH VOLUNTEER INCOME TAX ASSISTANCE (VITA) SITES. IN THE 2014 PROJECT, PARTICIPATING VITA SITES ASSISTED LOWER-INCOME INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES IN FILING OVER 40,000 TAX RETURNS TO CLAIM $77,724,820 IN TOTAL REFUNDS, OF WHICH $32,615,101 WERE EITC-RELATED REFUNDS.

column6: ENSURING OPPORTUNITY: PROVIDE LEADERSHIP FOR THIS COUNTY WIDE EFFORT TO REDUCE POVERTY IN CONTRA COSTA COUNTY. CAMPAIGN IS SUPPORTING ZERO2016 - AN EFFORT TO HOUSE ALL HOMELESS VETS BY 2016; CAL FRESH ENROLLMENT AND ACCESS; AND A REGIONAL STRATEGY TO INCREASE THE MINIMUM WAGE THROUGHOUT CONTRA COSTA COUNTY.SUMMIT: PROVIDE EDUCATION, TRAININGS AND WORKSHOPS FOR NON PROFIT LEADERS, EDUCATIONAL LEADERS, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND COMMUNITY LEADERS TO CLOSE THE DIVERSITY AND GENDER GAP IN SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING AND MATH FIELDS.CHEVRON OPPORTUNITY WEST: PROVIDES FOR TEACHING INSTRUCTION TIME TO SUPPORT ADULT LEARNERS READING AT OR BELOW A 6TH GRADE LEVEL. PROJECT SERVED 400 ADULT LEARNERS.CAPACITY BUILDING & SUMMER MINI GRANTS: LAUNCHED THE COMMUNITY LEADERSHIP INSTITUTE, PROVIDING A YEAR LONG TRAINING COHORT FOR EMERGING NONPROFIT LEADERS; SERVED 10 ORGANIZATIONAL LEADERS. HOST QUARTERLY TRAININGS AT RCF'S NONPROFIT RESOURCE CENTER IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE FOUNDATION CENTER - TRAININGS FOCUS ON FUND DEVELOPMENT, GRANTWRITING AND OTHER STRATEGIES FOR NONPROFIT SUSTAINABILITY. SUMMER MINI GRANTS WERE PROVIDED TO 7 ORGANIZATIONS TO SUPPORT SUMMER ENRICHMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR AREA YOUTH.DONOR ADVISED FUNDS: RCF WORKS WITH DONORS TO BUILD FUNDS AND MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR GRANTS FROM FOUNDATION ASSETS HELD IN NAMED COMPONENT FUNDS ESTABLISHED BY DONORS WHICH MEET THE FOUNDATION'S GRANTMAKING POLICIES.SPECIAL PROJECT: PROVIDING LEADERSHIP AND PLANNING ASSISTANCE FOR ANNUAL CONFERENCE FOR FOSTER CARE YOUTH AND PROVIDERS AND THE MY BROTHER'S KEEPER CONVENINGS. ALSO SUPPORTED COMMUNITY ACTION FOR URBAN REFORESTATION PROJECT TO PLANT TREES IN LOW INCOME NEIGHBORHOODS.SPECIAL PROJECT: SOLANO PLAYLOT. ASSIST COMMUNITY RESIDENTS IN BUILDING AND MAINTAINING A LOCAL COMMUNITY PARK.RICHMOND TREES: PLANTS TREES THROUGHOUT THE CITY OF RICHMOND TO CREATE AN URBAN FOREST. OVER 50 TREES WERE PLANTED AND CARED FOR IN 2014 AND 2015.MULTI-FAITH ACTION COALITION: PROVIDE LEADERSHIP AND SUPPORT TO THE MULTI-FAITH ACTION COALITION, REPRESENTING OVER 200 FAITH COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE COUNTY. THE COALITION HAS HELD QUARTERLY CAL FRESH ENROLLMENT DAYS, CONVENINGS ON HOMELESSNESS AND AFFORDABLE HOUSING, AND POVERTY SIMULATIONS FOR FAITH LEADERS.CAMPAIGN FOR GRADE LEVEL READING: A REGIONAL STRATEGY TO ENSURE THAT ALL CHILDREN READ AT GRADE LEVEL BY 3RD GRADE. DEVELOPED A COMPREHENSIVE COMMUNITY ACTION PLAN THAT INCLUDES STRATEGIES FOR EARLY LEARNING, CHRONIC ABSENTEEISM AND SUMMER AND OUT OF SCHOOL TIME LEARNING.

HOTELS: RWU IS CURRENTLY WORKING WITH TWO HOTELS, PILOTING THE RECOVERY OF FOOD AND ROOM ASSETS. THESE ASSETS INCLUDE, HALF TOILET PAPER ROLLS, HALF EMPTY TISSUE BOXES, SHAMPOOS AND CONDITIONERS FROM ROOM VANITIES. THE AMERICA HOTEL AND LODGING ASSOCIATION HAS EXPRESSED AN INTEREST TO WORK WITH RWU TO EXPAND THIS PROGRAM. ROCK AND WRAP IT UP - ADVOCACY: RWU WROTE AND HELPED PASS THE FEDERAL FOOD DONATION ACT 2008. THIS ACT ENCOURAGES FEDERAL BUILDINGS TO DONATE FOOR FROM THE BUILDINGS TO POVERTY FIGHTING AGENCIES INSTEAD OF ALLOWING IT TO BE THROWN OUT. RWU IS WORKING WITH FEEDING AMERICA. A FOOD BANK ADVOCACY ORGANIZATION, AND THE GENERAL SERVICES ADMINISTRATION TO ROLL OUT THIS ACT. ROCK AND WRAP IT UP ROCK AND WRAP IT UP - IS AN ANIT-POVERYY THINK TANK. USING GREENING TACTIC RECOVER FOOD AND OTHER ASSETS, WHICH ARE GIVEN TO AGENCIES FIGHTING HUNGER AND POVERTY, INCREASING THEIR OPERATING BUDGETS. THIS ALLOWS THE AGENCIES TO INVEST MORE RESOURCES IN SERVICES SUCH AS TUTORS, SOCIAL WORKERS, JOB PLACEMENT COUNSELORS AND MENTAL HEALTH COUNSELORS TO ATTACK THE ROOT CAUSES OF POVERTY. WE HAVE HELPED FEED OVER SEVENTY MILLION WHO HUNGER IN THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA.

CRISIS HOTLINE: TO PROVIDE CRISIS INTERVENTION, ADVOCACY SERVICES, COUNSELING AND INFORMATION ON DOMESTIC VIOLENCE. Dsc: LITERATURE - (EXPENSES: $462,996 ) (REVENUE: $4,854 )THE LITERATURE DEPARTMENT, THROUGH PUBLIC PROGRAMMING AND PUBLICATION OF REVIEW: LITERATURE AND ARTS OF THE AMERICAS PRESENTS WRITING FROM THE AMERICAS, FEATURING ICONIC AUTHORS AND EMERGING VOICES IN TRADITIONAL AND NEW GENRES, AS WELL AS COVERING HISTORICAL FIGURES. THIS YEAR, WRITERS AND SCHOLARS READ FROM THEIR WORK AND ENGAGED IN READINGS, CONVERSATIONS, AND BOOK PRESENTATIONS THAT EXAMINED SEMINAL TOPICS. THE RESPECTIVE PROGRAM SEASONS CULMINATED IN THE PUBLICATION OF TWO TIMELY ISSUES OF REVIEW. THE LITERATURE DEPARTMENT'S 20 EVENTS FEATURED AUTHORS INCLUDING 2014 PRESIDENTIAL MEDAL OF FREEDOM AWARDEE ISABEL ALLENDE, INTERVIEWED BY DEMOCRACY NOW! HOST AMY GOODMAN; CELEBRATED COLOMBIAN NOVELIST JUAN GABRIEL VASQUEZ (ALFAGUARA PRIZE); RENOWNED PUERTO RICAN WRITER ESMERALDA SANTIAGO, INTERVIEWED BY NEW YORK TIMES WRITER MIREYA NAVARRO; ACCLAIMED ARGENTINE AUTHOR LUISA VALENZUELA; AND REVIEW 89 GUEST-EDITOR NICOLAS KANELLOS IN CONVERSATION WITH AUTHORS CARMEN BOULLOSA AND ROLANDO HINOJOSA-SMITH. ADDITIONAL EVENTS INCLUDED A PRESENTATION CELEBRATING THE CENTENNIAL OF OCTAVIO PAZ'S BIRTH; A SPECIAL PANEL WITH PATRICIA ARIZA (CO-FOUNDER, TEATRO LA CANDELARIA) AND ACTRESS MIRIAM COLON; A BILINGUAL READING HEADLINED BY U.S. POET ANNE WALDMAN; AND AN EVENT HIGHLIGHTING DALKEY ARCHIVE PRESS. THE LATEST PRINT/DIGITAL ISSUES OF REVIEW 88 (BEYOND VIOLENCE: TOWARD JUSTICE IN LATIN AMERICAN WRITING/ARTS, SPRING 2014) AND REVIEW 89 (THE AMERICAS IN NEW YORK: WRITING AND ARTS IN LA GRAN MANZANA, FALL 2014) SHOWCASED TEXTS BY ESTABLISHED AND YOUNGER WRITERS FROM THROUGHOUT THE AMERICAS, INCLUDING HECTOR ABAD, JUAN GELMAN, YURI HERRERA, TATO LAVIERA, AND ELENA PONIATOWSKA; A HOST OF NOTED LATINO WRITERS; AND MEMORIAL PIECES ON OSCAR HIJUELOS AND ALVARO MUTIS.COMMUNICATIONS AND WEBSITE - (EXPENSES: $365,442 ) (REVENUE: $0)AS/COA ONLINE EXPANDED ITS REACH AS A TOP SOURCE OF INFORMATION FOR NEWS ABOUT THE AMERICAS, ATTRACTING NEW AUDIENCES AT RECORD RATES IN 2014. WHILE THE WEBSITE CONTINUED COVERING CRITICAL ISSUES IN EXPLAINERS AND COUNTRY UPDATES, FRESH CONTENT OFFERINGS, SUCH AS REGULAR INFOGRAPHICS AND CHARTS, HELPED MULTIPLY OUR AUDIENCE. OUR 2014 ELECTION GUIDE WAS A TOP-CLICKED PAGE, THANKS TO ONGOING COVERAGE OF PRESIDENTIAL VOTES, POLL UPDATES, AND ELECTORAL ISSUES IN LATIN AMERICA'S SEVEN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS. WE LAUNCHED A VIDEO SERIES, AS/COA ONLINE EXPLAINS, FEATURING INTERVIEWS WITH ANALYSTS, OFFICIALS, AND BUSINESS LEADERS ON TOPICS DEFINING HEMISPHERIC AFFAIRS. AND A NEW PODCAST SERIES KNOWN AS THE LATAM MINUTE SHARES QUICK UPDATES ON REGIONAL TRENDS WITH EXPERT INTERVIEWS. PAGEVIEWS GREW BY OVER 30 PERCENT AND THE NUMBER OF UNIQUE VISITORS ROSE BY ALMOST 40 PERCENT COMPARED TO 2013. WE ALSO REACHED READERS AND VIEWERS ON A VARIETY OF PLATFORMS AND IN NEW WAYS. OUR BROADCASTING CHANNEL AT LIVESTREAM.COM GARNERED 142,500 VIEWS, AN INCREASE OF MORE THAN 80 PERCENT OVER THE PRIOR YEAR. WELL OVER A DOZEN NEWS SITES FROM ACROSS THE HEMISPHERE CARRIED OUR LIVE WEBCASTS, INCLUDING ARGENTINA'S LA NACION, BRAZIL'S FOLHA DE SAO PAULO AND O ESTADO DE SAO PAULO, MEXICO'S EL UNIVERSAL AND CNN EXPANSION, AND U.S. OUTLET BLOOMBERG. YOUTUBE CHANNEL SUBSCRIPTIONS JUMPED 88 PERCENT, WHILE VIEWS ROSE BY 48 PERCENT. TWITTER ALSO GREW AS A TRAFFIC SOURCE BY 43 PERCENT. THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA, E-NEWSLETTERS, AND OUR WEBSITE, THERE ARE A NUMBER OF WAYS YOU CAN ACCESS CONTENT AND INTERACT WITH AMERICAS SOCIETY. MEMBERSHIP DUES- (EXPENSES: $0) (REVENUE: $54,351)NON-CONTRIBUTION PORTION OF MEMBERSHIP DUES.

AGING WITH GUSTO -AGING WITH GUSTO DISCUSSIONS IGNITE A MORE POSITIVE VIEW OF AGING. HOW WE THINK ABOUT OUR OWN AGING AND HOW WE TREAT OTHERS AS THEY AGE TAKES ON ADDED SIGNIFICANCE AS AMERICA AND THE WORLD AGE AT AN UNPRECEDENTED RATE. OUR SOCIETY FAVORS YOUTH AND SHIES AWAY FROM AGING. AGEISM IS ALIVE AND WELL AND CAUSES REAL HARM TO OLDER PEOPLE. PREJUDICE AGAINST PEOPLE AS THEY AGE COMES WITH A TWIST: IT IS DISCRIMINATION AGAINST OUR FUTURE SELVES. AGING WITH GUSTO DISCUSSIONS: 1) ENCOURAGE MORE POSITIVE VIEWS OF AGING; 2) HEIGHTEN APPRECIATION FOR THE CAPACITY OF PEOPLE OF ALL AGES TO CONTRIBUTE IN THEIR FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES; 3) INCREASE AWARENESS OF IDEAS, BEHAVIORS AND PRACTICES THAT ARE BASED ON MISCONCEPTIONS AND BIASES ABOUT OLDER PEOPLE; AND 4) DEVELOP IDEAS FOR HOW TO "AGE WITH GUSTO." THE VITAL AGING NETWORK HAS PARTNERED WITH ORGANIZATIONS SUCH AS LEADINGAGE MN, EPISCOPAL HOMES, THE YMCA, EBENEZER SENIOR HOUSING, THE MINNESOTA STATEWIDE ACTIVITY PROFESSIONALS AND OTHERS TO OFFER AGING WITH GUSTO DISCUSSIONS THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF MINNESOTA. ($1,221)VAN FORUMS - REGULARLY SCHEDULED FORUMS PRESENT SPEAKERS ON A VARIETY OF VITAL AGING TOPICS, INCLUDING HOUSING, TRANSPORTATION, ARTS, CIVIC ENGAGEMENT, SPIRITUALITY, PHYSICAL AND MENTAL HEALTH, AGING POLICY, LIFELONG LEARNING, MEDICARE ENROLLMENT, AND OTHER TOPICS RELEVANT TO OLDER ADULTS. ($14)MAPPING YOUR RETIREMENT -MYR, INC., A MINNESOTA NONPROFIT CONTRIBUTED ITS INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AROUND MAPPING YOUR RETIREMENT: A PERSONAL GUIDE TO MAINTAINING YOUR HEALTH, MANAGING YOUR MONEY, AND LIVING WELL TO THE VITAL AGING NETWORK IN 2014. MAPPING YOUR RETIREMENT ADDRESSES THREE CRITICAL ELEMENTS OF A MEANINGFUL RETIREMENT: LIVING YOUR LIFE, MAINTAINING YOUR HEALTH AND MANAGING YOUR MONEY. THE GUIDE BRINGS TOGETHER KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERTISE FROM 15 CONTRIBUTORS. TO QUOTE THE BOOK: "WITH GOOD HEALTH, GOOD LUCK AND GOOD PLANNING, RETIREMENT CAN BE A WONDERFUL NEW ADVENTURE. IT TAKES COMMITMENT, AND SOME ASSEMBLY IS REQUIRED. THE REWARD CAN BE A LIFE WELL LIVED." MAPPING YOUR RETIREMENT IS NOW AVAILABLE FOR PURCHASE FROM THE VITAL AGING NETWORK WEBSITE AND WORKSHOPS ARE SCHEDULED THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. ($1,380)

column6: THE OPTICAL DISPENSARY FILLS EYEGLASS PRESCRIPTIONS AND OFFERS A WIDE ARRAY OF CONVENTIONAL EYEWEAR AND LOW VISION DEVICES. THIS PROGRAM WAS TRANSFERRED TO JGB REHABILITATION CORPORATION IN SEPTEMBER 2014.THE STORE OFFERS THE LATEST PRODUCTS THAT MAKE DAY-TO-DAY LIFE EASIER FOR PEOPLE WITH VISION IMPAIRMENT, INCLUDING GLARE-FREE LIGHTING, HOUSEHOLD ITEMS, MAGNIFYING MIRRORS, WATCHES, CLOCKS, COMPUTER SOFTWARE AND CCTVS. THE PRINT ACCESS CENTER CONVERTS CONVENTIONAL PRINTED MATERIALS INTO ACCESSIBLE FORMATS BY ENLARGING OR SCANNING IT, OR BY TRANSLATING IT INTO AUDIO OR BRAILLE. SERVICES INCLUDING ENLARGING TEXT, TRANSCRIBING INTO BRAILLE, OR RECORDING AN AUDIO OF A WIDE VARIETY OF WRITTEN MATERIALS FOR INDIVIDUALS AND COMPANIES, SUCH AS MENUS, LETTERS, GREETING CARDS, EXAMS, SCRIPTS, AND HEALTHCARE PROVIDER MEMBER HANDBOOKS. WE ALSO OFFER A READING SERVICE WHICH PROVIDES ONE-ON-ONE READING TO VISUALLY IMPAIRED ADULTS TO SUPPORT THEIR EMPLOYMENT OR ACADEMIC ENDEAVORS. THE ARLENE R. GORDON RESEARCH INSTITUTE CONDUCTS STUDIES DESIGNED TO TRANSLATE SCIENTIFIC FINDINGS AND ADVANCES IN TECHNOLOGY INTO PRACTICAL SOLUTIONS THAT CAN HELP PEOPLE WHO ARE VISUALLY IMPAIRED FUNCTION MORE EFFECTIVELY IN EVERYDAY LIFE.SCHOLARSHIPS: SINCE 1980, WE HAVE BEEN HELPING A NUMBER OF OUTSTANDING LEGALLY BLIND STUDENTS EACH YEAR TO ATTEND COLLEGE OR ATTEND GRADUATE SCHOOL WITH SCHOLARSHIPS OF UP TO $10,000 EACH. SCHOLARSHIPS ARE BASED ON STRONG ACADEMIC ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND MERIT AND PROVIDE FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO HELP STUDENTS MAKE A SUCCESSFUL TRANSITION FROM HIGH SCHOOL TO COLLEGE OR ATTEND/REMAIN IN THE GRADUATE SCHOOL OF THEIR CHOICE. CANDIDATES ARE NOT REQUIRED TO DEMONSTRATE FINANCIAL NEED AND SCHOLARSHIPS ARE UNRESTRICTED.IN 2014, 7 SCHOLARSHIPS WERE AWARDED TO STUDENTS THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES. THE PISART AWARD IN VISION SCIENCE WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1981 AND RECOGNIZES AN EARLY-CAREER CLINICIAN OR SCIENTIST WHOSE NOTEWORTHY, INNOVATIVE AND SCHOLARLY CONTRIBUTIONS HAVE THE POTENTIAL FOR SUBSTANTIAL INFLUENCE IN THE UNDERSTANDING OF VISION LOSS, TREATMENT OF EYE DISEASE OR THE REHABILITATION OF PEOPLE WITH VISION LOSS. THE AWARD INCLUDES AN UNRESTRICTED CASH AWARD.

column6: Website: Our organization maintains a web-site with extensive research information on the writings of G.K. Chesterton. Great free and public access to many of his writings.
Research: The Amber collection is the careful finding and cataloging of all of Chesterton's works and transfering them onto a digital format for easy access.

Sales of books and merchandise related to G.K. Chesterton. Easy access to most of G.K. Chesterton's works in print in one location. Great resource for hard-to-find Chesterton books both new and used. Sale of promotional material to bring awareness to the public of this writer works and ideas.

Dsc: T.A./TRAINING/EDUCATION SERVICESP+P ALSO PROVIDES IN-DEPTH TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO OTHER ORGANIZATIONS ACROSS MINNESOTA IN TO BUILD THEIR CAPACITY TO RUN SUCCESSFUL FREE TAX PROGRAMS. IN 2014, P+P INCREASED THE NUMBER OF ORGANIZATIONS IT SERVES THROUGH THIS PROGRAM FROM 14 TO 17. THESE 17 ORGANIZATIONS OPERATED 39 FREE TAX SITES THROUGHOUT MINNESOTA, AND PROVIDED TAX ASSISTANCE TO NEARLY 16,000 ADDITIONAL HOUSEHOLDS.
